question: Good evening, London. It's nine o'clock, the fourth of November in the year 2019 and this is the voice of Fate broadcasting on 275 and 285 of the medium wave. People of London, be advised -- -- that Braxton and Streathon are quarantine zones as of today. It is suggested that these area be avoided for reasons of health and safety.
answer: Another radio in a room that seems to be of another world.

question: Good news following the productivity reports from Herefordshire indicating a possible end to meat rationing starting mid February. Police raided seventeen homes in the Birmingham area, uncovering what is believed to be a major terrorist ring.
answer: We move over a dressing bureau, past a wig and over a pair of black leather gloves, moving until we find the mask; it is like something from the masquerade ball of another era. It has an exaggerated goatee, harlequin cheeks and a smile, forever fixed, at once be-guiling and be-deviling.

question: Twenty eight people, eight of them women, are currently in detention awaiting trial. And that is the face of London tonight.
answer: The man, now fully dressed in cloak, hat, and mask gazes into the mirror.

question: You heard the man, sweetie. This rod's for your own good. What the hell --
answer: We're police officers, pal.

question: So bugger off!
answer: He's got a knife!

question: Gentlemen, I will hear your reports now. Mr. Heyer, speak for the Eye.
answer: We have less than two minutes of usable footage, Leader. It took the suspect less than a minute to dispatch the Finger's vice patrol. As you can see, the suspect's reflex speed is extraordinary. As is his strength.

question: Freeze it!
answer: I'm afraid the mask makes retinal identification impossible.

question: Good morning, London. This is the voice of Fate -- Damn. Good morning -- ack. Good morning Lond-- Goddammit! Where is my bloody tea?!
answer: Would someone get his lordship his bloody tea? Lewis, they want this report on the first hour --

question: I know. I know. Damned inconvenient this entire affair. Fine. Let's try again. Good morning, London. It is 6 am, the fifth of November 2019 and this is the voice of Fate. The new day brings good news and bright prospects from overseas, where negotiations with New China are moving in a positive direction. Last night's scheduled demolition of two deteriorating landmarks went off without a hitch. Spokesman for the Interior ministry said both structures were severely damaged and judged to be a danger to the unsuspecting public. Plans for new landmarks are well underway. Do you believe this crap, Dascombe?
answer: It's not our job to believe it, Lewis. Our job is to tell the people --

question: "Exactly what they tell us." I Know but do you think that people will believe it?
answer: They will if it's you that's telling it to them. Now let's try it again.

question: "Remember, remember, the fifth of November..." Do you suppose that's why he did it?
answer: Sir, who did what, sir?

question: Guy Fawkes. He tried to blow up Parliament. Don't they teach history in school anymore?
answer: Sir, we're both straight military, sir.

question: Get off of me!
answer: Lock the car doors.

question: I have a lighter... somewhere...
answer: What's happening --

question: Ah, Mr. Finch. I sent for you because what I have to say cannot be said over a phone or a radio. What I have to say cannot leave these four walls. Do I make myself clear?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: I believe in a few things, Mr. Finch. I believe in god. I believe in the destiny of the Nordic race. And I believe in fascism. The romans invented fascism. They had a symbol for it; a bundle of twigs bound together. One twig could be broken but a bundle would prevail. That is the heart and soul of fascism. Strength in unity. I tell you these things knowing full well that they make you uncomfortable.
answer: Well, I...

question: You have in fact expressed your discomfort in several arrest reports, arrests that were, in your opinion, "unnecessary." The fact that you are here, that you are not rotting in a prison cell, is a mark of my respect and admiration for you, for your craft, and for what you have done for this country. It is also because I know you, Finch. I know what you are. You're a man like me. A man who understands when they are given a job what must be done. I understand you, Finch, and that is why I can trust you. This terrorist knows us, Finch. These attacks are perfectly calculated and they are divisive. He knows what he's doing, Finch. He knows us all too well.
answer: You think he's an insider?

question: What I think is that this man must be stopped. Stopped at all costs and no one, I repeat, no one is to be placed above suspicion. Do I make myself clear?
answer: Perfectly.

question: England prevails, Mr. Finch.
answer: England prevails.

question: Ah, there they go. My happy and contented flock. Spiritually refreshed and ready to face the world again. Did you enjoy the sermon today, Dennis?
answer: Very inspiring, your grace. Though the segue of the forces of Satan among us did strike me as a bit of a curious digression.

question: Hmm, yes. A trifle purple, I thought. Still, Fate wanted it included and who are we to question the will of the almighty, miserable sinners that we are? And speaking of sin, I wonder which of the seven deadlies the good lord will see fit to tempt me with today.
answer: Perhaps pride, your grace.

question: I was thinking of something a little less ethereal. Has the young lady arrived?
answer: The agency informed me she'll be here directly. However, there was a mixup. It's not one of the usual girls. She's a little older.

question: Oh dear. Oh dear. Not too old, I trust?
answer: They promise me she's no more than fifteen.

question: Fifteen, hmm. Ah well, if Job could bear his disappointments, I suppose I must have the good grace to bear mine. Show her in when she arrives.
answer: Yes, your grace. The young lady, your grace.

question: Oh my! And to think I doubted your loveliness for even an instant. Mea culpa, my child, mea culpa. You are a vision. An angel.
answer: Uh... thank you.

question: Of course, "hate the sin, love the sinner." I always say. Take your dress off, please.
answer: Listen -- I was kind of hoping -- No --

question: You -- You filthy whore! I'll kill you, you fucking sow. What's this? Who -- Dennis?
answer: V? V, what are you doing? Oh no. You can't kill him! Oh god, V. I can't -- I can't --

question: There you go, baby. Now my baby boy can think so much clearer. Can't he? You have been thinking, haven't you? I know you have. Ever since this terrorist appeared. Oh jesus, that smile. That smile turns me on like nothing else. Tell me. Tell me what's going on in that ruthless sadistic brain of yours.
answer: Everyone is so worried about the terrorist. Especially Susan. You know why? Because nobody knows what he's going to do. If I were him, I know what I'd do. I'd blow that fat bastard to kingdom come.

question: No. You're kidding.
answer: Am I? There's an old train line under the New Government Building. It collapsed when they poured the foundation. You could haul in enough TNT to launch our Leader's ass all the way to the moon.

question: You're serious, aren't you?
answer: You need to be careful, Helen. Your mouth is going to get you into trouble one day.

question: Is that the same trouble you love putting in my mouth?
answer: You never know who might be listening.

question: Sorry it took so long. The boys had a devil of a time trying to filter out the background noise.
answer: Background noise?

question: The perpetrator apparently turned on the Bishop's stereo. Subsequently, a great deal of the tape is useless.
answer: What music did he play?

question: Beethoven. The fifth, I believe.
answer: Da, da, da, dum. That's code. Morse code.

question: Sir?
answer: For the letter "V". Anything on the girl yet?

question: No. The agency said somebody claiming to be Lilliman's valet canceled his Sunday appointment.
answer: What is it?

question: And then just Beethoven's fifth. We have got the initial path report back. The host was full of cyanide. And do you know what? When it reached his abdomen, it was still cyanide.
answer: Do you have a motive? I mean, was anything taken?

question: Just lives. I know it's too early for your profile but do you have any initial impressions?
answer: Well... He's incredibly powerful. This man's sternum was split like dry wood from the base all the way up to the manubrium. And he's resourceful. On that table behind you is a breakdown of all the chemicals found in Prothero's blood stream.

question: Bloody hell.
answer: There were hundreds of different chemicals in him. From trinitrotoluene to estrogen to motor oil.

question: Perhaps Fate will make something more of all this. I certainly can't.
answer: The Leader finally authorized an uplink for you? He must be getting nervous.

question: Quite. Government directed terrorism never sews healthy ideas into the public. Oh, that reminds me. Can you tell us anything about this? We found one in the carriage with Prothero and this one in the Bishop's quarters. A violet carson. I heard that strain had died off. Thought a botanist might shed some light on it. Delia?
answer: Yes -- Yes, of course.

question: What's all this, then, Harper? I get a radio that a man's down and in need of assistance?
answer: I ain't gone down yet but I sure do need some assistance.

question: Are you flat broke already?
answer: The one with the tits?

question: What I wouldn't give for a piece of that.
answer: I bet you get your chance with her sooner than later, Creedy, with the way Almond's crackin' up. Terrorist or no, if that bastard gives me another double shift, I'll stomp his fucking head.

question: Aye. This nonsense has put a serious strain on my drinking. I think I was actually sober today.
answer: We need to get a real man of the people in that director's position. Like Creedy here.

question: I got it!
answer: A connection?

question: Larkhill Resettlement Camp. Prothero's and Lilliman's employment records show they both help positions there at similar times.
answer: What about codename V?

question: Most of Larkhill's records were destroyed for security reasons but I did uncover an old standard procedures and operations manual. In special case studies, medical research groups used roman numerals to identify test inmates.
answer: Five is the letter V. Brilliant, Dominic. All we need is Larkhill's employment records.

question: That's the last entry until six months later when Dr. Surridge is back in London. There is no mention of the man in room five again. End of story. Except that it wasn't the end of the story. Between 2009 and 2012, over forty men and women who were previously stationed at Larkhill met with what were believed to be accidental deaths. Eventually, only three remained. The three he'd been saving until last. Everyone who worked at Larkhill. Everyone who could have identified him. You see there are two possible motives here. Not one. The first is revenge. He escapes from Larkhill and vows to get even with his tormentors. The whole exercise an elaborate, chilling vendetta. That's the explanation that I find most reassuring, funnily enough. Because that means he's finished. It's over now. The second motive is more sinister. Like I said, everyone who could have identified him is dead. What if he's just been clearing the ground? What if he's planning something else? You see, the diary we found was in full view. We didn't have to search for it. He left it there. He wanted us to find it. He wanted us to know the story. Or... For all we know, the diary could be a complete and utter fake. Codename V could have written it himself. He's playing games with us. He might never have been at Larkhill at all. Do you see? It could all be another smoke screen, a false trail, another cover story --
answer: Enough! Mr. Finch, would you please explain to me the nature of this meeting?! Because I was under the impression that you had some information about the terrorist, codename V! No more questions, understand! I want answers! I am not interested in where he grew up, what kind of flowers he likes or his favorite color! Do I make myself clear?

question: Yes, Leader.
answer: Dismissed. England prevails, Mr. Finch. Mr. Finch, the girl. Do you have anything on the girl?

question: Do you know why you're here. Evey Hammond?
answer: No, please, I didn't do anything.

question: Allow me to be more precise. Did you participate in the murder of Dr. Delia Surridge?
answer: No.

question: Did you participate in the murder of Derek Almond, director of the Finger?
answer: No, I --

question: Did you participate in the murder of Bishop Anthony Lilliman?
answer: Oh god, I don't --

question: Have you ever participated in a terrorist act against your country?
answer: No --

question: What is the identity of codename V?
answer: I don't know.

question: You are a lying cunt.
answer: They were going to rape me, kill me --

question: Finch! Do you know what this is all about?
answer: No, but I can guess.

question: What?
answer: "Remember, remember, the fifth of November."

question: Oh come on. He's long gone. He has to be. He did what he came to do and it's over. Isn't it?
answer: Not for us.

question: Yes, Mr. Dascombe, I do know it. It is that very fact that keeps me awake at night, wondering if perhaps there is a reason that Mr. Finch has failed.
answer: What are you saying?

question: I'm saying that perhaps I don't know you as well as I thought I did.
answer: Are you asking for my resignation?

question: Oh god, yes!
answer: "The most important member of my cabinet." Yes it is, isn't it, dear?

question: Oh, don't stop.
answer: I stop when you stop. What did he say next?

question: I can't --
answer: Come on, Peter, what are you afraid of? Almond used to tell me everything and you're twice the man he was.

question: He asked me... if I loved my country.
answer: Oh yes, I can tell you do love your country, almost as much as you love this...

question: Oh god...
answer: Go on.

question: Then he asked me to do something... oh, oh...
answer: What?

question: Helen, I can't. I can't tell you.
answer: He told you to frame someone as the terrorist.

question: My god?! How did you know that?
answer: I know Adam Susan. Now who was it?

question: No way. I can't tell you that.
answer: Yes you can, honey. You can and you will. You have to trust me, love. We're going to help each other.

question: Helen, please.
answer: Look at that face. You see? You're just bursting to tell me. Now who was it?

question: Who was it? Who was he? Roger Dascombe! Of course. Of course! It makes such perfect sense.
answer: Sir, I think there has been a mistake.

question: No! There is no mistake!
answer: But sir, there are people that say they saw both the terrorist and Dascombe together --

question: Who? Who are these people? They must be detained immediately. Whatever they saw or whatever they think they saw is subordinate to the truth and that truth is that Roger Dascombe is the terrorist and the terrorist is dead!
answer: But I thought I was the terrorist.

question: Finch, what are you doing here?
answer: Since I'm not in jail and since you have another, even more convenient suspect. I'm guessing the charges have been dropped.

question: Be careful, Finch.
answer: I am careful, sir. Always. That is why I suggest that a search of this building begin immediately.

question: The terrorist is dead!
answer: With all due respect, I disagree and I believe that he is presently trying to get out of this building disguised as one of us.

question: Are you challenging my authority?
answer: No sir, I'm trying to run an investigation --

question: Play it again.
answer: Come on, Finch. We've seen it fifty times. I mean, after what they done to you, I don't know why we're even trying to stop him.

question: I don't know. For twenty seven years, I've been at this job. Twenty seven years, I've done what I've been told to do. Maybe that's all there is to it. I'm just a dumb old dog. A dumb old dog that only knows one trick.
answer: That ain't it, Finch. It's more than that. I know you. It's something personal with this one.

question: Maybe. And maybe I'm not ready for a revolution.
answer: Well, we got less than thirty hours to stop it.

question: We will.
answer: How?

question: It's on the tape. I know it. I can feel it. He did this for a reason. He needs something.
answer: What?

question: The line of the Queen?
answer: But what does that mean?

question: Do you know what I want? I want you just like this... Bent over that black leather chair... What about Conrad?
answer: I told you, I'll handle Conrad and V will take care of Susan. The mob will take care of the guard and then... You can use the Finger to take over.

question: Use the Finger? You mean like this?
answer: Oh... oh... that is vulgar...

question: But you like it?
answer: Yes, oh yes, oh you're a pig, Peter...

question: That I am, misses. But I'm the pig that's gonna be running this country.
answer: Yes and I'm... I'm going to be Eva... Oh Eva... "Don't cry for me Argen... oh Argen... Argen... tina!

question: Eighteen hours. Dominic! Dominic, go home.
answer: But I've still got over three hundred lines from The Fairy Queen.

question: Forget it. There's no more time. You go home and get some rest. You're going to need it tonight.
answer: He's got us, doesn't he, Finch?

question: Now what's this all about, Mrs. Heyer?
answer: Please, forgive me. I've been so afraid, afraid to come here to talk to you. I thought he must know. I was terrified he knew but I had to come because I knew you were the only one that can protect me.

question: Protect you from what? Come now, Mrs. Heyer.
answer: You won't let him hurt me, will you?

question: Let who hurt you?
answer: The terrorist.

question: The terrorist is dead.
answer: Oh, how I wanted to believe it, Leader, but I know it's not true.

question: How?
answer: Because I know who the terrorist is.

question: How do you know?
answer: I saw him, Leader. In the middle of the night. I heard something. I went to the landing and that's when I saw it. That mask. That hideous smiling mask.

question: But how did you know it was Heyer?
answer: I know, Leader. I know the way a woman knows.

question: But you have no proof?
answer: Proof?

question: Yes, proof? This is an extremely delicate situation, Mrs. Heyer. It has been reported that the terrorist is dead. It would be a catastrophe to arrest a man now without concrete, conclusive proof. Do you have any evidence at all? But if you're right, if Heyer is indeed the terrorist...
answer: Leader! Wait!

question: Thank you, sir. I want you to go straight to your office and wait for me to call. When I do, I want you to come immediately home. Understood?
answer: Yes, Helen.

question: Oh, Conrad, I'm so proud of you.
answer: I did it, Helen. I did it, didn't I?

question: Tonight, Conrad.
answer: Tonight.

question: I'm coming with you.
answer: Sir --

question: There will be no discussion --
answer: But if Mr. Finch is right --

question: A dark figure stands over Creedy. The hammer raises, a slash of silver against the velvety darkness.
answer: V punches a button on the jukebox just as --

question: The hammer falls with a sickening soft crunch.
answer: The song begins to play; a melancholy song that says goodbye to love.

question: Blood pours down Creedy's snarling face, he snatches one of V's knives as another hammer blow cracks through his collar bone.
answer: V listens to the song, the smiling eyes somehow knowing.

question: The hammer falls again and again until the metal head is slick with blood and meat.
answer: The song continues.

question: This... this is a mistake.
answer: Don't tell me you're a coward, Mr. Finch.

question: Leader, we have to get out of here!
answer: This was your idea.

question: Good evening citizens of London. This is the voice of Fate. Your fate...
answer: What trick is this?

question: Tonight, the face of London is going to change and I am going to offer you the chance to change with her. Your Leader is finished. He will not leave these tunnels alive.
answer: This is an outrage! I order you not to listen to this!

question: At midnight tonight, the Head will be destroyed and a new era will begin. You must now decide if you are going to be a part of that era. You can choose to stay here and die with your Leader or you can choose to be free. The decision is yours and yours alone.
answer: Captain, order all your men to fall back and secure this position!

question: Traitors! You cowards! I know who you are! I'll see you hang! Every last one of you! Finch? Finch! Finch, goddammit, you can't leave me! Don't leave me! Damn you! Damn you! Conrad? Is that you? You're working with Finch, aren't you? And Creedy! You're all in this together! Who are you? Noooo!
answer: Don't move!

question: Mr. Finch! Oh god, Mr. Finch!
answer: Drop the knife.

question: Oh, I knew it, Mr. Finch. I knew you wouldn't desert me. You're a good man, Finch. A damn good man.
answer: No, Mr. Susan. No, I'm not. I'm a man who does his job and does what he's told. For twenty seven years, that's all I've been.

question: Careful, Mr. Finch. He's quick as the devil.
answer: I've read Delia's diary over and over all year. It sickens me but I am unable to judge her. I am as guilty as she.

question: Mr. Finch, what are you doing? Shoot him. Kill the bastard, Finch.
answer: I have no excuse. I did what I was told to do.

question: Finch, I order you to shoot him! Finch!
answer: My job was to find you and catch you. I've done my job. I've done it for the last time. I'm tired of it. I'm tired of it all. Kill him yourself if you can. Thank you, V. And goodbye.

question: Creedy? Creedy, you dumb bastard, you left your car parked in front. What did I tell you? Creedy. Oh my god.
answer: Helen...

question: Conrad! What have you done?
answer: I won, Helen. I did it. I won. I'm the better man. We've been through a bad patch, Helen. But now, he's gone... There's nothing to come between us...

question: Don't touch me! You stupid piece of shit! You've ruined it! I had it all planned perfectly and you've ruined it! I have to get out of here! I have to get away!
answer: Helen --

question: No! Let go! Now! Conrad, damn you! Let me go!
answer: No, Helen, you're not leaving me... not this time... not ever.

question: No, please! Oh god, no! Oh god, please help me!
answer: No one can help us, Helen. God is dead.
